abstract.text: A method is proposed to directly probe the Higgs boson compositeness using the unique characteristics of a boosted Higgs boson produced in association with a weak gauge boson (W ± , Z ).

The discovery potential for the upcoming LHC running is presented, showing that compositeness scales up to 3 TeV can be probed at the LHC with an integrated luminosity of L = 3000 fb −1 collected at √ s = 13 TeV.

body_text.text: Introduction

After the discovery of a particle consistent with the standard model (SM) Higgs boson [1][2][3] by the ATLAS and CMS Collaborations [4,5], intense research for the understanding of the details of the Higgs mechanism has commenced.
Experimental data does not rule out a possible composite nature of the Higgs boson.
In composite Higgs models, the Higgs boson is a (pseudo-) Goldstone boson emerging as a result of spontaneously broken global symmetry of a new, strong dynamics.
Like in QCD, there is a new fermion sector causing spin-1 ρ-like bound states with masses at the compositeness energy scale.

The ρ-like bound states (ρ 0 , ρ + , ρ − ) couple to SM particles and can hence be directly probed at the LHC through searches for single lepton events (ρ ± → ± ν) and searches for resonances decaying to two (ρ 0 → + − ) and three charged leptons (ρ ± → W ± Z → ± ν + − ).
Currently, the dilepton searches set the best limits on compositeness [6,7].
However, for a large part of the compositeness model phase space, the branching ratio (BR) of ρ 0 → + − falls very fast with the ρ mass.
Meanwhile, the BR of ρ → V H, where V = W ± , Z, reaches a maximum.
An observation of VH events in excess of what is expected a e-mail: maria.hoffmann@cern.ch by the SM and with an invariant mass at the TeV scale would be strong evidence for compositeness.
The decay products originating from heavy ρ decays are characterized by a very high transverse momentum ( p ⊥ ).
By exploiting this feature we propose a method to explore the presence of compositeness via the search for Higgs bosons with high p ⊥ .

This search is complementary to current searches using the dilepton invariant mass, and it may be more powerful than the latter in the parts of the compositeness model phase space where the BR ρ 0 → + − 0.5 %.

In this work we search for Higgs boson decays in the two channels providing the experimentally cleanest signatures for reconstructing the Higgs; the "golden" decay to four leptons, H → Z Z * → 4 , where = e, μ, and the decay to two photons, H → γ γ .
The addition of the H → bb mode is also discussed.

Since a Higgs originating from heavy ρ decays will carry a large p ⊥ , all non-SM backgrounds for H → Z Z * → 4 and H → γ γ decays are expected to be small and SM Higgs backgrounds will thus dominate.
In the H → bb channel the non-Higgs background is still significant.
The SM backgrounds can be strongly suppressed with a high Higgs p ⊥ requirement, which is the approach employed in this work.
With the proposed method we are able to set a direct limit on the existence of compositeness and its energy scale.

body_text.text: Monte Carlo samples
The results presented in this paper are based on Monte Carlo (MC) samples generated with MadGraph5 [23] and parton showered with PYTHIA [24].
To simulate the response of an LHC-like experiment, realistic resolution and reconstruction efficiencies for electrons, muons, photons and jets were applied with the Delphes framework [25].
The signal samples include the processes pp → ρ → V H, where the definitions from Sect.
1 apply.
These samples were generated at √ s = 13 TeV with the benchmark parameter values ξ = 0.1 and g ρ = 4.
Typical values for the ρ production cross section as a function of the ρ mass computed with MadGraph5 are presented in Table 1.
Numerical values of the BR for the processes ρ 0 → Z H, ρ 0 → + − , ρ ± → W ± H , and ρ ± → ± ν are shown in Table 2.
The Higgs boson in the signal samples decays via either of the two channels H → γ γ or H → Z Z * → 4 , where = e, μ.

In this study we consider the three main Higgs production mechanisms at the LHC; gluon-gluon fusion (ggF), vector boson fusion (VBF) and associated production (WH/ZH).

In the following we further assess the improvement of the search when adding the high BR channel H → bb.
This is done by extrapolating the results obtained for the H → γ γ channel using results from a recent combination reported by the LHC experiments in [21,22].
Analysis strategy
The analysis method presented in this paper aims toward optimizing the discovery potential of a composite Higgs during the upcoming LHC runs.

A discovery could come in the form of a direct observation of Higgs boson events with anomalously high p ⊥ or ρ decays to VH along with an excess of events with dilepton invariant mass at the TeV scale.

The distribution of the transverse momentum of SM Higgs bosons and of Higgs bosons produced from ρ decays is shown in Fig. 3. Given the noticeable difference in the shape of the distributions, the transverse momentum can be used as a discriminating variable to suppress the SM background.

The large transverse boost of these Higgs events causes the opening angle R = η 2 + φ 2 between the decay products (Z Z and γ γ ) to be significantly smaller than that from a SM Higgs, which is shown in Fig. 4. The characteristic R is not exploited in the present analysis strategy, but may be used in future searches to increase the sensitivity.
Event selection
A simple event selection inspired by the analysis strategies of ATLAS and CMS is implemented.
The H → γ γ signal is selected by requiring two hard photons with E T of the leading (subleading) photon being ≥ 40 (30) GeV.
Events from the H → Z Z * → 4 decay are selected by requiring two pairs of oppositely charged, same-flavor leptons.
The three leptons in the quadruplet with the largest transverse momentum must, in descending order, satisfy p ⊥ ≥ 20, 15, 10 GeV.

Muons, electrons and photons must, respectively, 1 The cross section of a Higgs boson produced in association with a pair of top or b quarks (tt H or bbH) is ≈ 3 times lower than the WH/ZH production at √ s = 13 TeV and therefore not considered in this study.
Since the applied event selection is simplified with respect to that of the LHC experiments, all samples are multiplied with analysis efficiencies representative of those presented by ATLAS and CMS.
These values were obtained at √ s = 8 TeV [19,20], and have been scaled to √ s = 13 TeV by assuming a slight increase in efficiency.
A factor of 0.4 is applied to the signal samples in both Higgs decay channels.
The factor applied to the H → Z Z * → 4 (H → γ γ ) background sample is 0.3(0.4) for ggF, 0.2(0.5) for VBF, and 0.5(0.5) for WH/ZH.
Furthermore, the signal is multiplied by a scale factor accounting for the increased detector fiducial acceptance, which is a consequence of the boost that causes the Higgs to be emitted at lower η.
The scale factor applied  to the H → γ γ channel is 1.2, while 1.3 is applied to H → Z Z * → 4 .

The contribution from the non-resonant QCD background in the γ γ + j j final state is estimated by extrapolating the obtained number of background events reported in [29] with the expected increase in production cross section [30], multiplied with the selection efficiency of the p ⊥ requirement.
This efficiency is estimated with a pp → γ γ + j j sample generated with MadGraph and found to be on the order of 10 −4 .
With an integrated luminosity of 3,000 fb −1 the number of expected events from this process is more than one order of magnitude smaller than what is expected from the dominant SM Higgs background.
This particular background is therefore considered safe to ignore.
Similarly, the contribution from the Z Z continuum ( pp → Z Z) is assumed to be negligible after the rather tight p ⊥ requirement.
The numbers of signal and background events per fb −1 remaining after the full selection are presented in Tables 3  and 4.
As seen, the contribution from ggF production is completely suppressed.

The expected impact of the inclusion of the H → bb channel is also considered.The problem with this channel is the presence of significant QCD non-SM Higgs background requiring careful subtraction and detailed treatment of systematics.
A realistic estimate of the impact of H → bb can be obtained using existing analyses in similar event topologies to the VH.

Recent studies at the LHC [21,22] showed that when searching for a Higgs boson produced via the tt H production mechanism, the expected significance increases by a factor of 1.7 when combining the H → γ γ channel with H → bb.
The result reported in [21,22] is based on a detailed, full simulation including all systematics.
Therefore, to realistically include the impact of the H → bb channel, the significance obtained here with the H → γ γ channel is extrapolated by the factor 1.7.
The significance as a function of the ρ mass scale (m ρ ) is considered for two integrated luminosity points: L = 300 fb −1 and L = 3000 fb −1 .
These sample sizes correspond to the expected integrated luminosity recorded after LHC and HL-LHC operation anticipated around the years 2020 and 2030, respectively [27].
The results obtained for the individual channels at √ s = 13 TeV are presented in Figs.
5 and 6 for m ρ in the interval 1.4-3 TeV.
As observed in Figs.
5 and 6 the diphoton channel is more sensitive than the four-lepton channel.
This feature is a result of the BR(H → γ γ ) being more than an order of magnitude larger than BR(H → Z Z * → 4 ).
The drop in significance with increasing m ρ is a result of the ρ production cross section decreasing with higher m ρ .
From Fig. 5 we see that a single LHC experiment with a data sample of L = 300 fb −1 is able to observe a signal with a significance of 3σ at m ρ ∼ 2.5 TeV.
With L = 3000 fb −1 the search is sensi- tive all up to m ρ ∼ 3 TeV.
A combination of ATLAS and CMS measurements with L = 3000 fb −1 can hence allow sensitivity to compositeness scales up to m ρ ∼ 3-4 TeV.

The 95 % CL sensitivity expected for the combination of the three channels for the SO(5)/SO(4) model considered here with m ρ ∼ g ρ f on the (ξ , m ρ ) plane is presented in Fig. 7 for three different luminosity scenarios.
The nonperturbative limit g ρ = 4π , where g ρ the physical coupling of the three ρ resonances, is also shown.
It is worth noting that this result might be modified if the impact of fermion resonances is taken into account.
This effect is highly model-dependent and relevant only if the ρ resonances interact directly with fermion resonances.
In this case the interactions of vector mesons with third generation quarks can be enhanced due to partial compositeness.
This does not affect the ρ production cross sections, but modifies the ρ decay widths into third generation quarks.

Moreover, if the fermion resonances are light (which is motivated by naturalness arguments) the decays of the vector meson into a SM fermion and a fermion resonance, and the decays of ρ into two fermion resonances, might become kinematically available.
This would make the impact on the width and branching ratios of the vector meson even stronger.
Summary and conclusions
In this paper the compositeness discovery potential for the upcoming LHC runs was presented.
A method was proposed to directly probe the Higgs boson compositeness by identifying boosted Higgs events from ρ → V H decays.

We have demonstrated that a search for compositeness is feasible with a data sample as small as L = 300 fb −1 collected at √ s = 13 The bands show the regions on the (ξ, m ρ ) plane that can be excluded using the combination of the channels H → γ γ , H → Z Z * → 4 , and H → bb.
The latter was obtained with an optimistic extrapolation of the results obtained with the H → γ γ channel with the results reported in [21,22].
The g ρ = 4π line defines the perturbativity boundary above which the effective lagrangian description breaks down TeV, which corresponds to the data sample recorded by the LHC in the year 2020.
The main result of this work is that compositeness scales up to g ρ f ∼ 3-4 TeV can be probed at the LHC with L = 3000 fb −1 by alone using the VH decay mode.
Combining the VH channel with dilepton and dijet searches could further increase the sensitivity and reach of the search.
The proposed search can immediately be employed in the Higgs analyses currently performed by the ATLAS and CMS experiments.
